commit.message:
Simplify warning filters in test suite (#7349)

* Move warning filters for test suite to pyproject.toml

I want to make our test suite configuration less complex and opaque.
Having a hidden `setup_test` with warning filters is less obvious than
using pytests official support for it.

Also remove filters that are not longer needed.

* Use compatibility variable for SciPy cg deprecation

* Ignore warnings due to using float64 limits

Neither NumPy's linspace nor called functions in our color module can
really deal with the max and min value supported by float64. As we might
deprecate this plugin system soon, just ignore it.

* Remove SKIMAGE_TEST_STRICT_WARNINGS_GLOBAL machinery

* Remove outdated warning filters

According to the CI apparently none of these are needed anymore...

* Add comment to warnings filter

tree 7187e71e871dc9608a766302a86191f6d2452019

committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1712143813 -0700

Simplify warning filters in test suite (#7349)

* Move warning filters for test suite to pyproject.toml

I want to make our test suite configuration less complex and opaque.
Having a hidden `setup_test` with warning filters is less obvious than
using pytests official support for it.

Also remove filters that are not longer needed.

* Use compatibility variable for SciPy cg deprecation

* Ignore warnings due to using float64 limits

Neither NumPy's linspace nor called functions in our color module can
really deal with the max and min value supported by float64. As we might
deprecate this plugin system soon, just ignore it.

* Remove SKIMAGE_TEST_STRICT_WARNINGS_GLOBAL machinery

* Remove outdated warning filters

According to the CI apparently none of these are needed anymore...

* Add comment to warnings filter

commit.message:
Disable cache when cache_active is False (#7333)

The cache dictionary was used even if cache_active was set to False. It was computed every time and, hence, used extra memory to store the result.

Co-authored-by: Marianne Corvellec <marianne.corvellec@ens-lyon.org>
Co-authored-by: Lars Grüter <lagru+github@mailbox.org>

verification.payload:
tree 3f1bac06cd6cebef6483bf1844b2fdb0d46c44e5
parent 9107d523a899b8d3767630941ac28f438bf875d2
author Maxime Corbé <maxime.pl.corbe@wanadoo.fr> 1710770583 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1710770583 +0100

Disable cache when cache_active is False (#7333)

The cache dictionary was used even if cache_active was set to False. It was computed every time and, hence, used extra memory to store the result.

Co-authored-by: Marianne Corvellec <marianne.corvellec@ens-lyon.org>
Co-authored-by: Lars Grüter <lagru+github@mailbox.org>

commit.message:
Deprecate output and positional args in `filters.gaussian` (#7225)

* Deprecate output and positional args in filters.gaussian

Addresses an item in our skimage2 transition list [1]. We can't simply
use deprecate_kwarg or remove_arg, as `output` can also be passed as a
positional argument. Instead, deprecate passing more than 1 positional
argument and at the same time, refactor `output` to `out`.

I'm not really sure whether remove_arg is a user friendly way to
deprecate a positional parameter. Applying the function prevents
positional arguments after the deprecated one as well, even though this
is not deprecated. The warning will users also not tell them about it.
I find it clearer to just deprecate these positional arguments in favor
of keyword-only ones. I also think it's the better practice.

[1] https://github.com/scikit-image/scikit-image/wiki/API-changes-for-skimage2

* Use deprecate_parameter

* Tweak docstring and error message

according to code review.

Co-authored-by: Marianne Corvellec <marianne.corvellec@ens-lyon.org>

* Set deprecation stop date according to guidelines

According to [1], deprecations should be inplace for two releases. If
merged this will be releases 0.23 and 0.24. So 0.25 will finalize the
deprecation.

[1] https://scikit-image.org/docs/dev/development/contribute.html#deprecation-cycle

* Apply suggestions from Marianne

Co-authored-by: Marianne Corvellec <marianne.corvellec@ens-lyon.org>

* Tweak error message for out

as suggested by Marianne. I felt like "got" conveyed the same meaning
as "provided" but is a bit less advanced vocabulary.

* Use assert_stacklevel

which was recently merged.

---------

Co-authored-by: Marianne Corvellec <marianne.corvellec@ens-lyon.org>

verification.payload:
tree 8cde3a67f9699408bfed6562a67893e799bf373f
parent bbffc2b63431933f73bd8b3c8cf6ca5ea55d74a9
author Lars Grüter <lagru@mailbox.org> 1710490902 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1710490902 +0200

Deprecate output and positional args in `filters.gaussian` (#7225)

* Deprecate output and positional args in filters.gaussian

Addresses an item in our skimage2 transition list [1]. We can't simply
use deprecate_kwarg or remove_arg, as `output` can also be passed as a
positional argument. Instead, deprecate passing more than 1 positional
argument and at the same time, refactor `output` to `out`.

I'm not really sure whether remove_arg is a user friendly way to
deprecate a positional parameter. Applying the function prevents
positional arguments after the deprecated one as well, even though this
is not deprecated. The warning will users also not tell them about it.
I find it clearer to just deprecate these positional arguments in favor
of keyword-only ones. I also think it's the better practice.

[1] https://github.com/scikit-image/scikit-image/wiki/API-changes-for-skimage2

* Use deprecate_parameter

* Tweak docstring and error message

according to code review.

Co-authored-by: Marianne Corvellec <marianne.corvellec@ens-lyon.org>

* Set deprecation stop date according to guidelines

According to [1], deprecations should be inplace for two releases. If
merged this will be releases 0.23 and 0.24. So 0.25 will finalize the
deprecation.

[1] https://scikit-image.org/docs/dev/development/contribute.html#deprecation-cycle

* Apply suggestions from Marianne

Co-authored-by: Marianne Corvellec <marianne.corvellec@ens-lyon.org>

* Tweak error message for out

as suggested by Marianne. I felt like "got" conveyed the same meaning
as "provided" but is a bit less advanced vocabulary.

* Use assert_stacklevel

which was recently merged.

Co-authored-by: Marianne Corvellec <marianne.corvellec@ens-lyon.org>

commit.message:
Address new copy semantics & broadcasting in `np.solve` in NumPy 2 (#7341)

* Use NP_COPY_IF_NEEDED for compatibility with new copy semantics

With NumPy 2.0.0, `copy=False` now raises a ValueError if the copy
cannot be made. The previous behavior to only copy if needed is provided
with `copy=None`. During the transition period, use this symbol instead.
Remove once NumPy 2.0.0 is the minimal required version [1, 2]

This approach was inspired by astropy [3].

[1] https://numpy.org/devdocs/release/2.0.0-notes.html#new-copy-keyword-meaning-for-array-and-asarray-constructors
[2] https://www.github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/25168
[3] https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/2390bf8f8f2a1c5b6beffbd87db9af5aa6538df1/astropy/utils/compat/numpycompat.py#L29

* Address new broadcasting rules in NumPy 2's `solve`

"The broadcasting rules for `np.solve(a, b)`` were ambiguous when b had 1
fewer dimensions than `a`. This has been resolved in a backward-
incompatible way and is now compliant with the Array API. The old
behaviour can be reconstructed by using
`np.solve(a, b[..., None])[..., 0]`."

https://numpy.org/devdocs/release/2.0.0-notes.html#removed-ambiguity-when-broadcasting-in-np-solve
https://www.github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/25914

verification.payload:
tree 32093d6f70772e63e086868f3ba7d7057cb823b3
parent 1e012db7eb02f52a5889ecc2950c102288b3c894
author Lars Grüter <lagru@mailbox.org> 1710411903 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1710411903 +0200

Address new copy semantics & broadcasting in `np.solve` in NumPy 2 (#7341)

* Use NP_COPY_IF_NEEDED for compatibility with new copy semantics

With NumPy 2.0.0, `copy=False` now raises a ValueError if the copy
cannot be made. The previous behavior to only copy if needed is provided
with `copy=None`. During the transition period, use this symbol instead.
Remove once NumPy 2.0.0 is the minimal required version [1, 2]

This approach was inspired by astropy [3].

[1] https://numpy.org/devdocs/release/2.0.0-notes.html#new-copy-keyword-meaning-for-array-and-asarray-constructors
[2] https://www.github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/25168
[3] https://github.com/astropy/astropy/blob/2390bf8f8f2a1c5b6beffbd87db9af5aa6538df1/astropy/utils/compat/numpycompat.py#L29

* Address new broadcasting rules in NumPy 2's `solve`

"The broadcasting rules for `np.solve(a, b)`` were ambiguous when b had 1
fewer dimensions than `a`. This has been resolved in a backward-
incompatible way and is now compliant with the Array API. The old
behaviour can be reconstructed by using
`np.solve(a, b[..., None])[..., 0]`."

https://numpy.org/devdocs/release/2.0.0-notes.html#removed-ambiguity-when-broadcasting-in-np-solve
https://www.github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/25914

commit.message:
Deprecate `skimage.morphology.skeletonize_3d` in favor of just `skeletonize` (#7094)

* Include skeletonize_2d in our public API and doc

* Deprecate skeletonize_3d in favor of skeletonize

instead of making skeletonize_2d public.

* Remove scaling in skeletonize_3d

Previously, skeletonize_3d returned a ubyte array whose values were
either 0 (background) or maxvalue (skeleton). maxvalue was determined
by scaling with img_as_ubyte and then taking the max. I don't really see
a value in this, the skeleton still has the same value everywhere, e.g.
labels with different values are not treated as separate objects /
skeletons. It just lead to unexpected behavior in [1].

[1] https://github.com/scikit-image/scikit-image/issues/7090

* Test that skeletonize doesn't modify original input

Due to skeletonize wrapping two algorithms handling and copying the
input is all over the place. In general, I'm trying to reduce the amount
of unnecessary copies while being tolerant with user input (dtype &
memory layout) and keeping the diff reasonable.

So a test seems like the best way to ensure that it stays that way.

* Remove unnecessary deprecation of skeletonize_2d

That function wasn't public before so we don't need to do a deprecation
cycle for it.

* Use consistend parameter description

across all skeletonize* functions.

Co-authored-by: Marianne Corvellec <marianne.corvellec@ens-lyon.org>

---------

Co-authored-by: Marianne Corvellec <marianne.corvellec@ens-lyon.org>

verification.payload:
tree 9d4930444093b5ce4d8d73a1fbb1c70ce692f4fb
parent 75e3efd713475fec3f96fdb9493068eee064cbc9
author Lars Grüter <lagru@mailbox.org> 1710369889 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1710369889 +1100

Deprecate `skimage.morphology.skeletonize_3d` in favor of just `skeletonize` (#7094)

* Include skeletonize_2d in our public API and doc

* Deprecate skeletonize_3d in favor of skeletonize

instead of making skeletonize_2d public.

* Remove scaling in skeletonize_3d

Previously, skeletonize_3d returned a ubyte array whose values were
either 0 (background) or maxvalue (skeleton). maxvalue was determined
by scaling with img_as_ubyte and then taking the max. I don't really see
a value in this, the skeleton still has the same value everywhere, e.g.
labels with different values are not treated as separate objects /
skeletons. It just lead to unexpected behavior in [1].

[1] https://github.com/scikit-image/scikit-image/issues/7090

* Test that skeletonize doesn't modify original input

Due to skeletonize wrapping two algorithms handling and copying the
input is all over the place. In general, I'm trying to reduce the amount
of unnecessary copies while being tolerant with user input (dtype &
memory layout) and keeping the diff reasonable.

So a test seems like the best way to ensure that it stays that way.

* Remove unnecessary deprecation of skeletonize_2d

That function wasn't public before so we don't need to do a deprecation
cycle for it.

* Use consistend parameter description

across all skeletonize* functions.

Co-authored-by: Marianne Corvellec <marianne.corvellec@ens-lyon.org>

---------

Co-authored-by: Marianne Corvellec <marianne.corvellec@ens-lyon.org>

commit.message:
Replace ignored teardown with autouse fixture in test_fits.py (#7340)

thereby making sure that follow-up tests are not affected by this
test.

Pytest has deprecated nose style `setup` and `teardown` [1]. It seems
those functions have been broken for some time now and we are slowly
seeing problems with it now.

[1] https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/changelog.html#id179

commit.message:
Deprecate function `plot_matches` in favor of `plot_matched_features` (#7255)

The overall goal is to use image0, image1 in function signatures which have image1, image2 inputs; this PR focuses on updating function plot_matches by refactoring it to `plot_matched_features`.

The overall goal is to use image0, image1 in function signatures which have image1, image2 inputs; this PR focuses on updating function plot_matches by refactoring it to `plot_matched_features`.

commit.message:
Include dates in release note headings (#7269)

Format release note headings more consistently. I also thought
including the release dates might be useful sometimes when
digging through commit dates etc.

It's ambiguous which minor release `release_0.12.rst` represents,
so I used the most recent one.

commit.message:
Add `assert_stacklevel` helper to check stacklevel of captured warnings (#7294)

* Add assert_stacklevel

* Use assert_stacklevel for existing origin checks

* Use assert_stacklevel were possible

I actually found a missing stacklevel=2 in `skimage.filters.median` this
way.

* Add tests for assert_stacklevel

* Apply suggestions from code review

Co-authored-by: Marianne Corvellec <marianne.corvellec@ens-lyon.org>

* Don't unpack warnings in assert_stacklevel

Using an `*` doesn't seem to provide any value here and makes
the most common usage pattern a bit more complicated.

---------

Co-authored-by: Marianne Corvellec <marianne.corvellec@ens-lyon.org>
